item.title: Timer not working properly
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

What? Never mind that. Java works in milliseconds, so if you put that number at 30, it will print almost immediately, if you put it at 3,000, it will print every 3 seconds.

Read full topic

item.title: Timer not working properly
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

usman555, please just stop, I know you’re trying to help.

System.currentTimeMills() returns the time that the application has been running for, in milliseconds.

A cheap, but working timer would be to just use a simple process type thing.

//start event
if (timer > 0) {
    //Do stuff
    timer--;
}

A good event manager would be a big benefit here.

Read full topic

item.title: Timer not working properly
item.dc:creator: @usman555 usman555
item.description:
@usman555 wrote:

Ah, that’s better.

There’s a built-in command in Java called System.currentTimeMillis that handles time.

Search for it in your files. The rest is pretty explanatory.

item.title: Timer not working properly
item.dc:creator: @usman555 usman555
item.description:
@usman555 wrote:

I don’t see what you’re trying to do here.

[code=java]
public static void main(String args[]){

int time = 0;

while (time < 10){
    System.out.println(time);
    time++;
}

}[/code]

While loop?

If you tell us what you need to do, then we could help you better.
